plants.name: Prunus serrulata
plants.description: A deciduous tree famous for its spectacular and delicate pink or white blossoms that appear in early spring, symbolizing renewal and the transient nature of life.
plants.location: Japan, East Asia, temperate regions worldwide
plants.funFact: Cherry blossoms bloom simultaneously over large areas, creating mesmerizing 'flower clouds' known as 'sakura' in Japan.

plants.name: Magnolia Ã— soulangeana
plants.description: A hybrid magnolia known for its large, tulip-shaped flowers that burst in early spring before the leaves unfold, adding vibrant color to gardens and parks.
plants.location: Temperate regions worldwide, native to China but widely cultivated
plants.funFact: Magnolia flowers are ancient, having existed before bees evolved, so they are primarily pollinated by beetles.

plants.name: Eschscholzia californica
plants.description: The state flower of California with bright, cup-shaped orange flowers that open in the morning sun and close at night or in overcast conditions.
plants.funFact: California poppies secrete a toxic alkaloid that deters some herbivores from feeding on them.

plants.name: Rhododendron ponticum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub producing large clusters of tubular, bell-shaped flowers that appear in early spring, popular in temperate woodlands and gardens.
plants.location: Native to Southern Europe and Western Asia, naturalized in the UK
plants.funFact: The nectar of Rhododendron ponticum contains toxins that can cause 'mad honey disease' if ingested by humans.
